Secondary Offense: off-label or unapproved promotion of medical products
Description: Schwarz Pharma Inc. agreed to pay $22 million to resolve False Claims Act allegations that the company failed to advise the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services that two unapproved products did not qualify for coverage under federal health care programs. Schwarz was alleged to have submitted false quarterly reports to the government related to a pair of drugs, Deponit and Hyoscyamine Sulfate Extended Release.

Primary Offense: off-label or unapproved promotion of medical products
Description: The U.S. subsidiary of Belgian pharmaceutical manufacturer UCB SA. pleaded guilty to the off-label promotion of its epilepsy drug Keppra and will pay more than $34 million to resolve criminal and civil liability arising out of its illegal conduct.
Agency: Food and Drug Administration referral to the Justice Department

Info Source: Extracted from a download of OSHA's Enforcment Data downloaded on 3/02/2022, available at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_catalogs.php

Secondary Offense: off-label or unapproved promotion of medical products
Description: Schwarz Pharma agreed to pay more than $9 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it misrepresented the status of drugs that had been deemed ineligible for reimbursement by government healthcare programs such as Medicaid. This was part of a larger $22 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-schwarz-pharma-inc

The Louisiana Attorney General's Office announced that it had obtained a total of $88 million in settlements from 25 pharmaceutical companies to resolve allegations they overcharged the state's Medicaid program.

Private Litigation Case Title: Ahrens et al v. UCB Holdings, Inc. et al

Primary Offense: off-label or unapproved promotion of medical products
Description: UCB Inc. agreed to pay $9.9 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it promoted the epilepsy drug Keppra for uses not approved by the Food and Drug Administration and thus caused false claims to be submitted to state Medicaid programs. This was part of a larger $34 million civil and criminal settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-ucb-inc

A group of 11 companies agreed to pay a total of $25.03 million to settle multistate litigation alleging they conspired to fix the prices of vitamins added to foods such as ready-to-eat cereals. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally among them.
